content.text: Is game development a good career?

Game development can be an incredibly rewarding career if you're passionate about creating interactive experiences. It combines technical skills, creativity, and problem-solving. That said, it can also be challenging with tight deadlines and periods of intense work. The indie path offers more creative freedom but less stability, while larger studios provide more resources but less individual control.
What game engine do you prefer?

I've worked with several engines, and each has strengths. Unity is fantastic for cross-platform development and rapid prototyping. Unreal Engine offers incredible visual fidelity and a powerful blueprint system. For some projects, I've even built custom engines when I needed specific performance optimizations. The best engine really depends on your project goals, team expertise, and target platforms.
Is VR the future of gaming?

VR is definitely a significant part of gaming's future, but I see it as one branch rather than the entire future. VR offers unparalleled immersion, but traditional gaming has advantages in accessibility, session length, and certain gameplay styles. I think we'll see continued growth in VR gaming alongside mobile, console, and PC gaming, with each platform serving different experiences and player preferences.
What's your approach to game design?

I focus on core gameplay loops first - what will players be doing moment-to-moment, and is that inherently satisfying? I prototype early and iterate based on playtesting. I believe good games respect players' time and intelligence. The most important question I ask is 'Is this fun?' And if not, why not? Technical excellence is important, but engaging gameplay is essential.
